div.head: THE Preface of JOHN LANGIUS TO THE READER.
div.p:
HAving not long ≈øince obtained this little Book, which I here Publi≈øh, from a mo≈øt excellent knowing Man of the≈øe Matters, it plea≈øed me ≈øo much, that I pre≈øently con≈øulted to impart it for thy profit; and this drove me to it, that this genuine Author ≈øeemed almo≈øt to be the only Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øor and Worker, in our Age, of the Phy≈øical Tincture, and to have Compo≈øed his Work to that very end, that he might be known to be an Adepti≈øt when it ≈øhould come forth, and that the Wanderers in this Art might be reduced to
the right path; and then withal the candour and per≈øpicuity of the Writing, as it were a continued Style of Sendivogius, who≈øe foot≈øteps this Author doth every where clo≈øely follow, yea ≈øometimes excel, but alwaies indeed doth excellently explain without making it his aim at all: Wherefore I was confident that if I ≈øhould divulge it, both the afore≈øaid worthy intention of the Author would be ≈øatisfied, and a clear light kindled in the dark night of Errours to very many, who until this very day either by dolorous Labour, or pre≈øumptuous Learning, or continual ince≈ø≈øant Sighs (although alas! now and then their hopes do fail them) do hunt after the great Elixir of the Philo≈øophers. For although
within the≈øe few years ≈øome numbers have ambitiou≈øly endevoured to obtain the Title of True Philo≈øophy, and pre≈øumed under the vizard of a fal≈øe name to in≈øtruct, or rather to di≈øtract and make mad all the World with phanta≈øtick Books; nay have drawn ≈øome ignorant Men, and tho≈øe not ob≈øcure ones, upon the ≈øtage, not without the laughter of the more di≈øcrect and learned; yet neverthele≈øs the ≈øharper witted, and ≈øuch as have conver≈øed (as the Proverb goes) more familiarly with dead Philo≈øophers, pre≈øently found out their hooks and baits; ≈øo that ≈øhortly after tho≈øe fruitful promi≈øers, who ≈øwel'd with ≈øuch great words, became for≈øaken of their Admirers (like the A≈øs who was ≈øtript of the Lions skin) and being
left to them≈øelves, have alwaies born their ≈øhot among≈øt fal≈øe Coiners, and paid the utmo≈øt farthing. But this Author, which we now dedicate to the common good, as he hath the ≈øtyle and thrid of the ingenious Philo≈øophers, and ob≈øerves it every where, yea as he every way breaths the primordial and ancient Chymi≈øtry, and ≈øhowes him≈øelf abundantly by his own ≈øigns; ≈øo I hope it will come to pa≈øs, this Sun being ri≈øen, that the fal≈øe Stampers will at length quite be di≈øpelled and vani≈øh like the fog and ≈ømoke. Truly who, or what kind of Per≈øon, was Author of this ≈øweet Mu≈øt-like Work, I know no more than he who is mo≈øt ignorant; nor (≈øince he him≈øelf would conceal his name) do I think fit to
enquire ≈øo far to get his di≈øplea≈øure; neverthele≈øs it is clear enough he is beloved of God like another Daniel, and is a Man of mo≈øt hearty true de≈øires, if he ≈øtill be living; and one who at that Age attained to the Medicinal, Chymical and Phy≈øical Arcana's of the Philo≈øophers, in which many others hardly attain the lea≈øt tittle, and that but very ≈øuperficially: Certainly it will be a very hard matter to find any one who like to him hath gathered this Art out of Books at ≈øo tender an Age; Thomas Norton profe≈ø≈øeth he had the knowledge of the White Tincture at Twenty eight years of Age; and Helmontius relates how Theophra≈øtus Paracel≈øus, at the ≈øame Age received the Gold-making Medicine; ≈øo Diony≈øius,
Zakarias, and perchance ≈øome few other Young-men, are reported to have attained it: But the≈øe had it from other mens help and tutoring, which is not ≈øo much to be wondred at, when as therein their capable wit is only to be commended: But to pick out the Ro≈øes from the mo≈øt thorny Bu≈øhes of Writings, and to make the true Elixir of Philo≈øophers by his own Indu≈øtry, without any Tutor, and at Twenty three years of Age; this perchance hath been granted to none, or (as is ≈øaid) to mo≈øt few hitherto. Who will gain≈øay but that in a perticular manner God hath poured down this occult Science into ≈øuch a wit through the open windows of Heaven; when as I believe millions that have followed
the ≈øame ≈øtudy, and run that ≈øtage to their old Age, have ≈øweat at the ≈øame for fifty, fixty years, more or le≈øs, with all the toiling labours could be thought upon. Therefore let us the more re≈øpect this highly enlightened Author, in regard that he being (as 'twere) ≈øo largely overwhelmed by Almighty God with ≈øuch great and unu≈øual Ble≈ø≈øings, hath not done like the Cithari≈øt A≈øpendius, who u≈øed to ≈øing and play privately to him≈øelf; But what he had learned without envy, he would as benignly communicate without envy. How envy hath prevailed with many others in their ≈øetting forth the≈øe ≈øecret Arcana's, and how therewith they have hedged their Writings (as with a Partition-Wall) round about, needs not here to be remembred,
every Chymical Searcher can te≈øtifie the ≈øame. The Off≈øpring of former Philo≈øophers held it rather to be for their commendation thus to delude their Po≈øterity, and they triumphed under envy with Chymerical Juglings, ju≈øt as we read in the Eu≈øebean Greek Writings of Scaliger, That Democrates Abderites had ob≈øcurely written of Gold, Silver, Stones and Porphyr; the like did al≈øo Mary an Haebrean wi≈øe woman; who were taught by O≈øtanes how they ≈øhould cover the Art with many witty Riddles, but withal not to write without envy. But our Author, being taught in a better School, hath ≈øeque≈øtred the Chymical Art from all vulgar errours; and the Sophi≈øms being thrown out, and the curious
dreams of the Conceited hi≈ø≈øed away, hath ≈øo candidly, clearly and per≈øpicuou≈øly de≈øcribed his own Matters, that you ≈øhall not find ≈øo many things more clearly ≈øet forth by any one, as Alethea (or the truth her ≈øelf) will ju≈øtifie: Yea, if tho≈øe things which Mary Rant (an Engli≈øh woman) by inward Revelation promi≈øed concerning the making of Gold (that it would become vulgar or common in the year 1661.) come to pa≈øs within an hundred years after, then I doubt not at all but it hath taken ≈øome beginning from this. He chu≈øeth to follow Sendivogius his foot≈øteps, yet both with a better order and far more exact di≈øtinctions; be it ≈øo though, that he taught more ob≈øcurely concerning the true ≈øubject of Philo≈øophers
than Sendivogius (I ≈øay more ob≈øcure to the ≈øight of young Beginners, who may perchance draw it more ea≈øily from Sendivogius) yet neverthele≈øs he that ≈øearches more curiou≈øly and without preconception of his opinion, ≈øhall a≈ø≈øuredly find a greater light from him than from Sendivogius; but in the re≈øt Sendivogius dares not place him≈øelf before him, nor any other, either of the old or of the following Ages: Oh! how far are the Rivers Merrha and Siloam from one another? How much di≈øparity is between the≈øe and other Writings, which hitherto endevoured to hinder the blindfolded World from her precipice and ruine? Yet I would it had plea≈øed this mo≈øt worth Author, to have committed to the publique Pre≈øs
his noble and poli≈øht writings him≈øelf (for I hear he hath al≈øo written a Dialogue concerning the watry Fire, or Liquor Alkahe≈øt) then I could not doubt but we ≈øhould have all more correct and perfect. Now, although I have been mo≈øt diligent and careful, yet (as it often falls out in ≈øuch matters or ca≈øes) becau≈øe I was to u≈øe a Manu≈øcript, not ≈øo very exact, I dare not affirm that all things ≈øtrictly agree with the words of the Author; for oftentimes, where the ≈øen≈øe was manife≈øtly difficult, it was made plain by the alteration or change of a ≈ømall letter; neverthele≈øs we have been ≈øtudiou≈øly wary, that where≈øoever any firm ≈øen≈øe might be gathered, there we would not ra≈øhly alter it. We hartily wi≈øh, and humbly pray
(if the Divine Author be yet living) That either he him≈øelf would commit his Writings corrected and prepared according to his mind to be printed: Or if he de≈øign to make u≈øe of our ≈øervice, That he will plea≈øe to convey to our hands the true Manu≈øcript (after any manner he think fit) and we ≈øhall e≈øteem, or repute it for a great Honour to have our things well corrected for our love to the Publick Good, having no other aim at all.

Kind Reader, do thou interpret all this to the be≈øt con≈øtruction, con≈øidering that if the≈øe (like ≈øome Patrimonial Trea≈øures, had travailed longer under the communication of private Copies, perhaps in a little time either many more Faults and Enormities (by blanks, or blind Letters, or wearing) had ≈ølipt in, or el≈øe the true ≈øen≈øe it ≈øelf had by little and little been
utterly ≈øpoyled; which to how many Treati≈øes of ≈øingular Note it hath hapned unto, is not needful here to enlarge. I will ≈øay no more, for I do not here attempt to write a Commentary: The≈øe things I have touched for my own ≈øake only, lea≈øt either the Author him≈øelf might ≈øu≈øpect I would al≈øo undertake the ≈øame again≈øt his Book, which of old, the true Sun (≈øo called) pre≈øumed again≈øt Sendivogius: or el≈øe any others perchance might cen≈øure me (as the whole World is now full of Bu≈øie-bodies.) However it be, in this I would do a kindne≈øs to the Lovers of Chymistry, and ≈øatisfie the de≈øires of many. If I ≈øhall ≈øee this hath been acceptable, perhaps more may follow: But if otherwi≈øe (yet I avoid to pre≈øage) God ble≈øs the Benevolent Reader, and farewell.

div.head: The Authors Preface.
div.p:
I Being an Adept Anonymon, and Lover of Learning, and a Philo≈øopher, I decreed to write this little Treati≈øe of Medicinal, Chymical and Phy≈øical Arcana's, in the year of the Redemption of the World, 1645. but in the three and twentieth year of my Age, that I might pay my duty to the Sons of Art, and might lend my hand to bring them out of the labyrinth of Errours, wherein they are intangled, and that it might appear to the Adepti≈øts that I am a brother and equal to them; and that tho≈øe ≈øeduced by the deceits of Sophi≈øters, might ≈øafely return, ≈øee and embrace the true Light: I do al≈øo further pre≈øage, That not a few will be enlightened by the≈øe my Labours; they are no Fables but real Experiments,
which I have ≈øeen, made, and do know, which an Adepti≈øt will ea≈øily gather by the≈øe Lines. Wherefore as I write the≈øe things for the good of my neighbour, let it be enough, that I profe≈øs there is none that ever writ in this Art ≈øo clearly; and that many a time in writing I ‚Ä¢ aid a≈øide my pen, becau≈øe I was rather willing to have concealed the Truth under the Mask of Envy, ‚Ä¢ ut God compelled me to write, whom I could not re≈øi≈øt, who alone knows the heart, to whom only be Glory for ever. Hence I undoubtedly gather, many will become Ble≈ø≈øed in this la≈øt Age of the World with this Arcanum, by rea≈øon I have written faithfully; nor have I willingly left any thing doubtful for a young Beginner, which is not perfectly ≈øatisfied. Al≈øo I know many who, with me, do enjoy
this Arcanum, and am per≈øwaded there are many more who≈øe new familiarity ≈øhortly (as I may ≈øay) I ≈øhall be daily acquainted with. Let the holy Will of God do what it plea≈øeth; I confe≈øs my ≈øelf unworthy by whom ≈øuch things ≈øhould be effected; yet in the≈øe matters I adore the holy Will of God, to whom all created things are bound to be ≈øubjected; for which cau≈øe only he did create them, and being created, pre≈øerves them.

THe true Manu≈øcript Copy, which John Langius in his Preface doth ≈øo much thir≈øt after, is here Publi≈øhed for thy benefit; in which thou wilt find con≈øiderable enlargements and explanations, wherein the Latin Tran≈ølation is deficient, as witne≈ø≈øeth Chap. 15. &c.

CHAP. 1. Of the nece≈ø≈øity of the Sophick ‚òø for the Work of the Elixir.
div.p:
WHo≈øoever de≈øires to enjoy the ≈øecret Golden-Fleece, let him know, That our Gold-making POWDER (which we call our Stone) is only Gold dige≈øted unto the highe≈øt degree
of purity and ≈øubtile fixity, whereto it may be brought, by Nature and a di≈øcreet Arti≈øt; which Gold thus e≈ø≈øen≈øificated, is called Our Gold (and no more vulgar) and is the period of the perfection of Nature and Art. I could cite all the Philo≈øophers that write of this Thing, but I need no witne≈ø≈øes; becau≈øe my ≈øelf being an Adepti≈øt, do write more clearly than any heretofore. Yet be it as it will, thou can≈øt never do any thing without fire: It was not then in vain, that the Truth-telling Hermes, next to the Father ‚òâ, and Mother ‚òΩ, reckons the fire as the third or governour of the whole. There is al≈øo another Furnace, which is called Our common Furnace, which is either of Brick or Potters Loam, or of Iron or Copper plates well luted within; this Furnace we call an Athanor, who≈øe form, that be≈øt plea≈øeth me, is a Tower with a Ne≈øt. Let the Tower be about two Foot high or more, and nine Inches broad within the plates, or a common ≈øpan; about two Inches broad below of each ≈øide, and ≈øo about ≈øeven Inches high, or eight at the mo≈øt; that where the fire is, may be thicker of Clay than at top, but of a ≈ømooth a≈øcent, ≈øomewhat tapering; next to the bottom or foundation, let there be an a≈øh-hole three or four fingers high, or a little more, and a grate and ≈øtone fitted to it; a little above the
grate about an Inch high, let there be two holes which may give vent into a Ne≈øt, which mu≈øt be clo≈øe joyned at the ≈øide, the holes let them be about an Inch diameter, and the Ne≈øt capable to receive three or four Egg-gla≈ø≈øes, and not too large; let the Ne≈øt and the Tower be very free from cracks, and let the Ne≈øt have no ≈øcope downwards below the di≈øh, but that the fire may come immediately under the platter, and ≈øo forth at two, three, or four holes, and let the Ne≈øt have a cover with a window in it, where a gla≈øs about a Foot high may ≈øtand, or el≈øe the top of it let out at a hole above; and being thus ordered, ≈øet your Furnace in a light≈øome place, and the Coals are to be put in at the top, fir≈øt live ones and then others, and the top to be ≈øhut from all Air with a cover, and ≈øifted a≈øhes in the joynts of it. In ≈øuch a Furnace you may do the Work, from the beginning to the end.

But if you be curious, you may find other, and other waies of admini≈øtring a due Regimen of Fire. Let then, for a general Rule, ≈øuch an Athanor be made, in which, without motion of the gla≈øs, you
may give what degree of heat you will, from a feveri≈øh heat to a ≈øoft reverbering or dark red, and in its highe≈øt degree, let it la≈øt at lea≈øt ten hours or eight, without recruiting with Coals, for le≈øs time is toyl≈øom to the Workman; then ha≈øt thou the fir≈øt gate open.

Thou maye≈øt, when thou ha≈øt the Stone, make the fore-mentioned Furnace portable (as I my ≈øelf have) for it is ea≈øily portable, and the Operations are not ≈øo tedious, but very ≈øhort, and ≈øo need no great Furnace; which would be wor≈øe to carry about, and more trouble than the ri≈øing a little ≈øooner than ordinary, to recruit a ≈ømall Furnace with Coals for about a Weekes time, or two or three at the mo≈øt, in the time of Multiplication.

div.head: CHAP. 19. Of the Progre≈øs of the Work in the fir≈øt Forty Dayes.
div.p: HAving prepared our Sol and our ‚òø, ≈øhut them in our Ve≈ø≈øels and govern them with our Fire, and within Forty Dayes thou ≈øhalt ≈øee thy whole matter turned into a ≈øhadow or Atomes, without any vi≈øible mover or motion, or without any heat perceptible to the touch, ≈øave only that it is hot.
But if you be yet ignorant both of our Sun and of our ‚òø, meddle not in this our Work, for expence only will be thy lot, and no gain nor profit.
But if only thou want the full di≈øcovery of our Sun, having throughly attained the skill of our ‚òø, and knowe≈øt how to fit it to the perfect body, which is a great My≈øterie.

Then take of ‚òâ vulgar well purified one part, and of our ‚òø fir≈øt illuminated three parts, joyn them as was before taught, and ≈øet them to the Fire, giving a heat in which it may boyl and ≈øweat;
let it be circulated day and night without cea≈øing, for the ≈øpace of ninety dayes and nights, and thou ≈øhalt ≈øee in that ≈øpace, that thy ‚òø will have divided and reconjoyned all the elements of thy Gold; boyl it then other fifty dayes, and thou ≈øhalt ≈øee in this Operation thy ‚òâ vulgar turned into our ‚òâ, which is a Medicine of the fir≈øt order: Thus doth it become our true üúç, but it is not yet a teyning Tincture. Tru≈øt me, many Philo≈øophers have wrought this way, and attained the Truth, yet it is a mo≈øt tedious way, and it's for the Grandees of the Earth. Moreover when thou ha≈øt got this üúç, do not think that thou ha≈øt the Stone, but only its true Matter; which in an imperfect thing thou maye≈øt ≈øeek, and find it in a week, with our ea≈øie, but rare way, which God hath re≈øerved for his poor contemned and abject Saints: Of this thing I have now determined to write much, although in the beginning of this Book, I decreed to bury this in ≈øilence; for here lies the knot on which the grand Sophi≈øm of all the Adepti is built: Some write concerning ‚òâ and ‚òΩ vulgar, and they write true; and again
others deny ‚òâ and ‚òΩ vulgar, and they al≈øo ≈øay true. I being now moved with Charity, will now reach forth my hand, and therein I dare appeal to all the Adepti that ever wrote, and tax them all with Envy, yea, and I my ≈øelf that had re≈øolved to tread in that ≈øame path of Envy, but that God did inforce me beyond what I intended, to whom be everla≈øting Prai≈øe. I ≈øay then that each way is true, for it is but one way in the end, but not in the beginning; for our whole Secret is in our ‚òø, and in our ‚òâ; our ‚òø is our way, and without it nothing is done; our ‚òâ al≈øo is not ‚òâ vulgar, yet in ‚òâ vulgar is our ‚òâ, el≈øe how could Metals be homogeneal? If then thou know how to illuminate our ‚òø as it ought to be, thou maye≈øt for want of our ‚òâ joyn with Gold vulgar, but yet know that the acuation of the ‚òø ought to be different for the one, and for the other, and in a true Regimen of them, in an hundred and fifty dayes, thou ≈øhalt have our ‚òâ, for our ‚òâ naturally comes out of our ‚òø: If then ‚òâ vulgar be by our ‚òø divided into its Elements, and afterwards joyned, all the mixture, by the help of the fire, will become our ‚òâ,
which then being joyned with that ‚òø, which we prepared, and call our Virgins Milk, by reiterate decoction it will give all the ≈øigns which the Philo≈øophers have de≈øcribed, in ≈øuch a fire as they have written of in their Books.

But now if you ≈øhall in your Decoction of ‚òâ vulgar (though it be mo≈øt pure) u≈øe that ≈øame ‚òø which is u≈øed in our ‚òâ (though both flow from one root in general) and apply that Regimen of heat, which the Wi≈øemen in their Books have applyed to our Stone, thou art without all doubt in an erroneous way, and that is the great Labyrinth in which almo≈øt all young Practitioners are entangled, for there is ≈øcarce one Philo≈øopher who in his Writings doth not touch both wayes; which is indeed but one way fundamentally, only one is more direct to the Mark than the other: They then that do write of ‚òâ vulgar, as we ≈øometimes in this Treati≈øe, ≈øo al≈øo Artephius, Flammel and Ripley, with many, others; We are not otherwi≈øe to be under≈øtood, but that our Philo≈øophical ‚òâ is to be made out of ‚òâ vulgar and our ‚òø, which then by reiterate Liquefaction, will give a üúç and Argent Vive, fixt
and incombu≈øtible, and who≈øe Tincture will abide all Tryals; al≈øo in this ≈øen≈øe, our Stone is in every Metal or Mineral, fora≈ømuch as ‚òâ vulgar may be extracted out of them, and out of that ‚òâ our ‚òâ may be made, as being nearer in it than any Metal. So then our Stone is in all Metals, but in our ‚òâ and ‚òΩ nearer than in any other; Therefore, ≈øaith Flammel, ≈øome wrought it in ‚ôÉ, ≈øome in ‚ôÑ; but I wrought it in Sol, and there I found it. Yet there is in the Metallick Kingdom one thing of a miraculous Original, in which our Sol is nearer to be ≈øought than in Sol and ‚òΩ vulgar, if it be ≈øought in the hour of its Nativity; which melts in our ‚òø like Ice in warm water, and yet it hath a re≈øemblance with Gold: This is not to be found in the manife≈øtation of Sol vulgar, but by revealing that which is hidden in our ‚òø, the ≈øame thing may be found by Dige≈øtion in our ‚òø for the ≈øpace of an hundred and fifty dayes. This is our Gold, ≈øought the farthe≈øt way about, which is not yet of ≈øo great a vertue as that which Nature hath made and left to our hands; yet turning the wheel thrice, each comes to one end, yet with this
difference, what thou finde≈øt in the one in ≈øeven months, thou mu≈øt wait for in the latter the ≈øpace of a year and a half, or it may be two years. I am acquainted with both wayes, and commend the fir≈øt to all ingenious men, but in my De≈øcriptions I have mo≈øt touched the harde≈øt way, le≈øt I ≈øhould draw on my head the Anathema of all Philo≈øophers; know then, that this is the only difficulty, in reading the books of tho≈øe that are mo≈øt candid, that all, one as well as the other, do vary the Regimen, and when they write of one Work they ≈øet down the Regimen of another, in which ≈ønare I was entangled my ≈øelf at fir≈øt, and it was long before I could get free out of this Net.

Know then that the Fire in our Work is mo≈øt agreeable to Nature, if thou under≈øtand our Work aright; but if thou work in Sol vulgar, that properly is not our Work, and yet it leads directly into our Work in its determined time; but in it thou neede≈øt a ≈øtrong and long decoction, and a proportionable time; then maye≈øt thou go on the ≈øecond Operation with our mo≈øt benign Fire, with our
Tower and Athanor, which I chiefly commend.

If then the Work in Sol vulgar be ≈øure to procure the Marriage of Diana, Venus in the beginning of the E≈øpou≈øals of thy ‚òø, then put them into the Ne≈øt, and in a due heat of Fire thou ≈øhalt ≈øee an emblem of the great Work, to wit, Black, White, Citrine and Red; then reiterate this Work with ‚òø, which we call our Virgins Milk, and ≈øet it in a heat of Balneum Roris at the highe≈øt; let it be a heat of a≈øhes mixed with ≈øand; then thou ≈øhalt ≈øee not only the black but the blacke≈øt black, and all blackne≈øs; ≈øo al≈øo both the white and the red complete, and this with a gentle proce≈øs; for in the fire and the wind God was not, but in the ≈øtill Voice he ≈øpoke unto Elias.

Therefore if thou knowe≈øt the art of it, extract our Sol out of our ‚òø, then ≈øhall thy Secrets ≈øpring all out of one Image, which, tru≈øt me, is more perfect than any worldly perfection, according to the Philo≈øopher; If, ≈øaith he, thou know how to make the Work out of ‚òø alone, thou ≈øhalt be Ma≈øter of a mo≈øt pretious Work. In this Work are no ≈øuperfluities, but the
whole (by the Living God) will be turned into purity, becau≈øe the action is only in one thing.

But if thou ≈øhalt proceed in our Work with Sol vulgar, then the action and pa≈ø≈øion is a twofold ≈øub≈øtance, and only the middle ≈øub≈øtance of both is taken, and the Faeces rejected; if you do but meditate well on what I have told, in few words, you have a key to open all the appearing Contradictions which are among≈øt the Philo≈øophers; therefore Ripley teacheth to turn the wheel round thrice, in his Chapter of Calcination, to which Relations his threefold Doctrine of Proportions agreeth, wherein he is very my≈øtical, and tho≈øe three different proportions agree to three ≈øeveral Works; one Work is mo≈øt ≈øecret and purely natural, which is with our ‚òø and our Sol, to which Work belong all the ≈øigns de≈øcribed by the Philo≈øophers. This Work is done neither by fire nor by hands, but only by internal heat, and the external is only expelling cold and overcoming its Symptomes.

The other Work is in Sol vulgar, purged with our ‚òø; this operation is done
with a ≈øtrong fire, and in a long time, in which both are decocted by the mediation of Venus, ≈øo long until the pure ≈øub≈øtance of each be ≈øublimed, which is the true juyce of Lunaria, this is to be taken, and the faeces are to be rejected; this is not yet our Stone, but our true üúç; which then is to be decocted again with our ‚òø, which is its own blood, by which decoction it becomes a Stone, penetrative and teigning.

Thirdly and La≈øtly, There is a mixt Work, where ‚òâ vulgar is mixt with our ‚òø in a due proportion, and a Ferment of our üúç is added as much as is ≈øufficient; then are fulfilled all the Miracles of the World, and the Elixir becomes able to furni≈øh the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øor both with Riches and Health: Seek then our üúç with all thy might, which, believe me, thou ≈øhalt find in our ‚òø,

Otherwi≈øe chu≈øe Sol vulgar, and work on it with a due proportion of heat, and out of it (in time) thou ≈øhalt prepare our Sol and Luna; but it's a way hedged with infinite briars, and we have made a Vow unto God and Equity, that we would never,
in naked words, declare each Regimen; for I can a≈ø≈øure you, upon my credit; that I have in other things di≈øcovered the truth plainly. Take then that ‚òø which I have de≈øcribed, and unite with Sol to which 'tis mo≈øt friendly, and in ≈øeven moneths, in our true Regimen of heat, thou ≈øhalt for certain ≈øee all which thou de≈øire≈øt, or in nine moneths, or ten at the mo≈øt; but our ‚òΩ in its full thou ≈øhalt ≈øee in five moneths: And the≈øe are the true periods of this üúç, out of which, by reiterate decoction, thou ≈øhalt have our Stone and permanent Tinctures, through the grace of God, to whom be all glory and honour for ever.

div.head: CHAP. 20. Of the appearing of Blackne≈øs in the Work of Sol and Luna.
div.p:
IF thou ≈øhalt work in Sol or ‚òΩ to our üúç, in them con≈øider if you ≈øee this matter like to pa≈øte, and to boyl like unto water, or rather like to melted pitch; for our Sol and ‚òø have an emblematical Type in Sol vulgar, joyned with, and decocted
in our ‚òø: When thou ha≈øt kindled thy Furnace, wait for the ≈øpace of 20 dayes and nights, in which time thou ≈øhalt ob≈øerve divers colours, and about the end of the fourth week, if the fire be continual, thou ≈øhalt ≈øee a mo≈øt amiable greenne≈øs, which will be ≈øeen for about ten dayes, le≈øs or more, then rejoyce, for without doubt in a ≈øhort time thou ≈øhalt ≈øee it like unto a coal in blackne≈øs, and all the members of thy Compound ≈øhall be turned into Atomes, for the Operation is no other than a Re≈øolution of the fixt in that which is not fixt, that afterwards both being joyned together, may make one matter, partly ≈øpiritual, and partly corporal: Therefore ≈øaith the Philo≈øopher, Take Cora≈øcene Dog and Bitch of Armenia, joyn them together, and they ≈øhall beget thee a Son of the colour of the heaven; for the≈øe Natures, in a ≈øhort decoction, ≈øhall be turned into a broth, like unto the foam of the Sea, or like a thick cloud, which ≈øhall be tinctured with a livid colour; and once more I may a≈ø≈øure thee, that I have not hidden any thing ≈øave only the Regimen, and this, if thou art wi≈øe, thou ≈øhalt ea≈øily collect from my Lines: Suppo≈øing
then that thou wilt learn the Regimen.

Take the Stone which I have told you of before, and govern it as you know how, and there ≈øhall follow the≈øe notable things; fir≈øt, as ≈øoon as our Stone ≈øhall feel the fire, it ≈øhall flow (its üúç and its ‚òø together) upon the fire like to wax, and the üúç ≈øhall be burned, and the colour ≈øhall change day by day; but the ‚òø is incombu≈øtible, only it ≈øhall be affected with the colours of the üúç for a time, but it cannot be radically affected, therefore it will wa≈øh Letton clean from all its filth; reiterate the heaven upon the earth, ≈øo long and ≈øo often, until the earth receive a ≈øpiritual and heavenly nature: O ble≈ø≈øed Nature, which doth that which is impo≈ø≈øible for Man to do! Therefore when in thy gla≈øs thou ≈øhalt ≈øee thy Natures to be mingled like unto a coagulated and burnt blood, know that then the Female is embraced by the Male: Therefore after the fir≈øt ≈øtirring up of the Matter, expect that in 17 dayes thy two Natures ≈øhall be turned into a bloody or fatted Broth, which ≈øhall be turned round together, like unto a thick Cloud, or the ≈øcum of
the Sea, as is before ≈øaid; and the colour of it will be exceeding ob≈øcure; then be ≈øure that the Kingly Child is Conceived, and from that time thou ≈øhalt ≈øee vapours, green, blew, black and yellow, in the Air or Fire, and at the ≈øides of the Ve≈ø≈øel. The≈øe are tho≈øe Winds, which in the forming of our Embryon are very frequent, which are to be kept warily, le≈øt they fly out, and the Work be de≈øtroyed; beware al≈øo of the Odour, le≈øt it happen to exhale at any chink; for the vertue of the Stone would thereby get a mo≈øt notable detriment; therefore the Philo≈øopher commands to keep the Ve≈ø≈øel clo≈øe ≈øealed, and beware that you do not break off abruptly from the Work; neither open nor move the Ve≈ø≈øel, nor yet intermit the Operation not an hour, but continue the Decoction till you ≈øee the moi≈øture begin to fail, which will be in about thirty dayes; then rejoice, and re≈øt a≈ø≈øured that thou art in the right way. Attend the Work vigilantly, for in about two weeks from the time, thou ≈øhalt ≈øee the whole earth dry and notably black, then is the death of thy Compound at hand, the Winds are cea≈øed, and all are
re≈øt and quietne≈øs. This is the fatal Ecclip≈øe of the Sun and of the Moon, when no light ≈øhall ≈øhine upon the Earth, and the Sea ≈øhall vani≈øh, then is made our Chaos, out of which, at the command of God, ≈øhall proceed all the Miracles of the World in their orders.

div.head: CHAP. 21. Of the Burning of the Flowers, and how to prevent it.
div.p:
THe burning of the Flowers is an errour of fatal con≈øequence, yet ≈øoon committed before the Natures which are tender and extracted from their profundity, they are oftentimes burnt; this errour is chiefly to be heeded after the three weeks; for in the beginning there is ≈øo much moi≈øture, that if the Work be governed by a ≈øtronger fire than is convenient, it being brittle will not bear the abundance of winds, but will ≈øuddenly fly in pieces, unle≈øs the gla≈øs be too large, and then ≈øure the vapours will be ≈øo out of mea≈øure di≈øper≈øed, that they will hardly return again to their body, at lea≈øt
not ≈øo much as is nece≈ø≈øary for the refre≈øhment of the Stone. But ≈øo ≈øoon as the earth ≈øhall begin to retain part of its water, then the vapours decrea≈øing, the fire may be ≈øtrengthened without danger of the Ve≈ø≈øel; but the Work will neverthele≈øs be de≈øtroyed, and will have a colour of a wild Poppie, and the whole Compound will at length become a dry and unprofitable powder, of a half red colour: Thou ≈øhalt conclude from this ≈øign, that thy fire hath been too ≈øtrong, ≈øo ≈øtrong, to wit, as to hinder true conjunction; for know, that our Work doth require a true change of Natures, which cannot be until an entire union of both Principles be made; but they cannot be united but in the form of water, for bodies may be confounded or blended together, but cannot be united, nor yet can any body with a ≈øpirit be united per minima; but ≈øpirits with ≈øpirits may well be united, therefore our Operations mu≈øt become Homogeneal Metallick Water; the way to which Solution is our foregoing true Calcination, which therefore is not an ex≈øiccation properly, but a kind grind of water, as earth in Atomes;
which when they become more ≈øubtle than the exigencies of the earth requires, earth is then actually tran≈ømuted into, and doth receive the form of Ferment of water; but if the fire be too vehement, this ≈øpiritual Nature being ≈øtruck as with a fatal ≈øtroke, our active will become pa≈ø≈øive, of ≈øpiritual corporal, even a red unprofitable precipitate, for in a due heat the colour will be as black as that of the Crow, which though it be dark yet it's mo≈øt de≈øirable; yet there is al≈øo a blackne≈øs which will appear in the beginning of the true Work, and that very remarkable, but this is ever accompanyed with a due proportion of moi≈øture, and ≈øheweth that heaven and earth have been in conjunction, between which the fire of Nature is conceived; by which redne≈øs all the concave of the gla≈øs will ≈øeem as it were gilt over with Gold, but this colour is not durable long, but in a ≈øhort ≈øpace will be changed into a greenne≈øs, then in a very ≈øhort time expect blackne≈øs; and if thou wilt be patient, thou for certain ≈øhalt ≈øee thy de≈øire accompli≈øhed, at lea≈øt make ≈ølow, but ≈øure progre≈øs. Let not thy heat be over ≈øtrong,
and yet ≈øtrong enough, and between Scilla and Charibdis ≈øail like unto a skilful Pilot, ≈øo ≈øhalt thou attain the wealth of either India; ≈øometimes thou ≈øhalt ≈øee as it were little I≈ølands ≈øloating, and ≈øhooting out as it were little ≈øprigs and buds, which will be changeable in colours, which ≈øoon will be melted and others will ari≈øe in the ≈øtead of them; for the earth as it were inclining to a Vegetation, is alwaies ≈øending forth ≈øome new thing or other; ≈øometimes thy fancy will be that thou ≈øee≈øt in thy gla≈øs Birds or Bea≈øts, or creeping things, and thou ≈øhalt each day behold colours mo≈øt beautiful to ≈øight, which though they are plea≈øant to the eye, are not of a long continuance; all is in the keeping of a due heat without any intermi≈ø≈øion: So ≈øhall all the≈øe plea≈øant colours in the ≈øpace of fifty dayes end in a colour mo≈øt black, and a powder di≈øcontinuous, which if thou ≈øee≈øt not, blame either thy ‚òø or thy Regimen, or the di≈øpo≈øition of the Matter, unle≈øs thou either ha≈øt moved or medled with the gla≈øs, which may either protract or finally de≈øtroy the Work.

div.head: CHAP. 22. The Regimen of Saturn, what it is, and whence it is denominated.
div.p:
AS many of the Wi≈øe men as have wrote of this Ma≈øter-piece of Philo≈øophy, have all ≈øpoken of the Regimen of ‚ôÑ, which many (under≈øtanding wrong) have turned a≈øide unto divers errors, and deceived them≈øelves with their own opinion; ≈øome being thus led with a great deal of confidence, although with very little advantage: But know that our ‚ôÑ is more noble than any Gold, it's the Limus in which the ≈øoul of our Gold is joyned with its ‚òø, that after they may produce Adam and Eve his wife; therefore that which is the highe≈øt ≈øhall ≈øo humble it ≈øelf as to become the lowe≈øt, then expect that he will redeem all his Brethren by his blood. The ≈øepulchre in which our King is buried is named ‚ôÑ in our Work, and its the Key of the Work of Tran≈ømutation; O happy is he that may behold this ≈ølow Planet! Pray to God, my Brother, that he would vouch≈øafe
to you his ble≈ø≈øing; for its not of him that willeth, nor of him runneth, but on the Father of Lights alone, this Ble≈ø≈øing dependeth.

div.head: CHAP. 23. Of the various Regimens of this Work.
div.p:
BE certainly confident ≈øtudious Son of Art, whoever thou art, that nothing is hidden in this Work, ≈øave only the Regimen, of which, that of the Philo≈øopher may be verified, Whoever is Ma≈øter of that Science, Princes and Grandees of the Earth ≈øhall honour him. I a≈ø≈øure you, upon the word of an hone≈øt Man, that if this one Secret were but openly di≈øcovered, Fools them≈øelves would deride the Art; for that being known, nothing remains, but the Work of Women and the play of Children, and that is Decoction: So that not without cau≈øe did the Wi≈øe men hide this Secret with all their might. And re≈øt a≈ø≈øured that we have done the ≈øame, whatever we have ≈øeemed to ≈øpeak concerning the degree
of heat; yet becau≈øe I did promi≈øe candor in this Treati≈øe, ≈øomething at the lea≈øt is to be done, that I may not deceive the ingenious of their hope and pains: Know then, that our Regimen, from the beginning to the end, is only lineal, and that is to decoct and to dige≈øt, and yet this one Regimen in it ≈øelf comprehends many others, which the envious have concealed, by giving them divers names, and de≈øcribing as ≈øo many ≈øeveral Operations: We, to perform the candor we promi≈øed, will make a far more per≈øpicuous manife≈øtation. So that, Reader, whoever thou art (if ingenious) thou ≈øhalt find cau≈øe to acknowledge our candidne≈øs in this to be more than ordinary.

div.head: CHAP. 24. Of the fir≈øt Regimen of the Work, which is of Mercury.
div.p:
